dialogue: What a surprise! What are you doing here?
I was in the neighborhood. Thought I’d say hello.
Have you been getting my messages?
My machine’s been on the fritz.
No harm, no foul! Oh, it’s so good to see you, Thel. You look terrific.
Pshh... I’m a balloon. What’s all this? You’re doing a play?
Annie. I got Daddy Warbucks.
Hey, that’s a big part!
I was not expecting it.
I think about Teddy often. Such a special guy. What’s it been, two years now?
Just about two.
Five since Sheryl. Still feels like a dream. How are you holding up?
I’m... holding.
Such a loss.
Let’s not be maudlin. You gonna show me your place?
Got a TV. Plants. Window-- You mind? Most infections start from the hands. I read that. Our director’s been trying to get me to touch Gloria in the scene where I adopt her. But I won’t do it.
A little fridge. That’s Gary.
We call him Starey-Gary. It’s not an insult, just a thing that happens. I don’t think he minds.

Isn’t she a beauty? Four wheels. 43 miles per charge. Electronic auto braking system. Bright red so everyone can see me comin’. And a little basket for whatever you need really. I like to put bread in there. Not a whole bread. Little pieces of it.
You put them in loose?
No, no, in bags. Ziploc.
You think I could I borrow it?
Borrow my scooter?
I’m in a bit of a situation--
Wha?
I’m in a bit of a situation. I just... it’s a headache. The less you know the better.
If it involves my scooter it involves me.
I don’t want to say in front of Gary.
Gary, could you give us a second?
Is he gonna listen?
I’m not sure. But he’s going to watch.
You got a telephone?
I got scammed. But I have the address where I sent the money. It’s a P.O. Box in Sun Valley. I’m headed there today. To figure out who took it and get it back.
What are you nuts? That’s absurd. You should call the police.
They’re no use.
What about your family?
Not with this.
It’s a bad idea--
You got a better one?
You’re not thinking straight. You’re grieving. At least you have your health. Be grateful for that.
Why don’t you stay for lunch? They’ve got a wonderful cafeteria. Beautiful melons. Fresh.
Sure. But would you mind if I give it a try? May be in the market for one.
I love driving. I miss it.
Nice and easy...
Winston, can I borrow your scooter?
Winston?
I’m taking it!
Thel!
Stay there! I’m coming to you! Cornered, she starts accelerating toward him. The two scooters charge toward each other, getting closer and closer... They’re about to collide.
Oh my god!
Don’t laugh, Winston!
Oy god...
Let’s just talk--
Everybody wants to talk, my god! I just need your scooter. Please be a doll and don’t make a fuss.
My grandson is parked a block away. I don’t have much time...
You left your grandson in the car?
He’s 24.
Ben, please don’t make me go through you.
You couldn’t. You know I’ve got a titanium hip.
Shall we put that to the test? I’m going. With or without you.
I can’t let you do this on your own. I won’t.
I need to be back by eight! It’s opening night. I can’t miss it.
I got it, I got it.
Why does this street look so familiar?
We’re stopping by Mona’s.
Mona. God, I haven’t seen her since Berlin.
That was a fun trip, wasn’t it? When was that-- ‘95?
‘98, I think. The flight was bumpy. Otherwise it was terrific. You know she’s obsessed with me. We never acted on it but she would stare at my legs when I was in short pants.
Whatever you say, buddy. If you’re right, maybe we can use it. Then--
...Why are we going to Mona’s?
To get a gun.
OH MY GOD! Why do we need a gun?
It’s just a precaution! A couple of shmegeggies like us turning up unannounced? I like to be prepared.
Would you even know how to use it?
How hard could it be? Idiots use them all the time.
I don’t think we should have a gun.
So what if we get there and he has a gun? Then what?
If he has a gun... then I’d like us to have a gun too.
You’ll have to distract her. Mona’s still sharp. It’s not gonna be so easy.
She’s still on Benedict?
Yeah, she’s unbelievable. Same house, no help. She doesn’t drive, you know, but that’s about it.
Maybe I can do my monologue.
I’d rather you didn’t.
Mona?
Good to see you, doll.
Are you alright?
Oy god...
Elderberry... Goji...
ANNIE, GET YOUR BLASTED, FLEA￾RIDDEN, GODDAMN HOUND OUT OF MY
Chaim took this. My cousin. Did you ever meet Chaim? From Hinsdale? He’s not doing so hot. But it’s a beautiful picture.
She shouldn’t be living like that.
She’s managing.
How is she getting her meals? When’s the last time she got out of that chair? She’s wasting away.
We all have good days and bad days.
What’s today?
We’ll find out.
...Gary’s gonna wonder where I am.
What is it with you-- you miss that place?
I like it there.
What’s to like?
I’m swimming twice a week. There’s wonderful classes. I just took Geography for Seniors.
Why “for Seniors?” Wouldn’t it be the same for everybody?
...The print is bigger. And they skip over some of the smaller countries. There’s also cooking classes, painting, grief counseling, Oopsy Upsy--
Oopsy Upsy?
A professional comes in and shows us how to pick each other up when we fall. There’s a tub lift, a shower lift, a dual lift-- for when a couple falls at the same time.
Does that happen often?
It’s rare but it happens. Usually on a hill. You have to use each other’s weight as counterbalance.
Sounds... interesting.
Sheryl used to cook. Pick up our socks, keep the place together. I’ll take help where I can get it. I’m not ashamed. God forbid someone makes life a little easier, right?
It’s not the same.
Why?
I always picked up the socks.
Isn’t that interesting. They’re different Gary’s. But both Gary.
How do you two know each other?
I guess we don’t.
What is happening?
It’s my grandson.
We can’t make that.
Hang on.
What is it?
I-- I don’t know where we are.
Don’t say that.
I don’t recognize this area. It’s totally different--
I knew this would happen. I follow your lead and look what happens!
Okay, Ben thank you--
I’m gonna find help.
No, no, I just need a moment, to orient myself.
Excuse me!
Hey! Don’t make a scene-- Ben whirls around--
You didn’t listen to me, Thel. You don’t listen to anybody!
If I listened to you I’d be your roommate by now! Go home, Ben. You don’t want to be here.
I think we should call your family.
Out of the question!
What about your grandson?
...No, no--
Why?
Because I’m not like you. As much as you want me to be. Sorry to disappoint but I like to be useful.
We’re more alike than you think.
What’s that supposed to mean?
We’re old! Frail. Diminished. Liabilities for the ones we love.
What’s to worry about? I move from point to point. I don’t complain. I’m the same. Maybe you would be too if you stopped feeling sorry for yourself!
That’s not how this works--
Sure it is! You start acting like a baby and people treat you like a baby.
BULLSHIT! You know how I know? Because I couldn’t hear her! When she fell. We’re not what we were.
We’re the only ones left, Thel.
The least we can do is take care of each other. Call your family.
I don’t need them. I don’t need you. I just needed your scooter!
...We were stopped.
Did you put the parking break on?
I didn’t know there was one. I didn’t know that... I’m sorry, Ben.
You’re not sorry.
Where are you going?
I’m not waiting!
Thelma?
Okay. Okay.
Thank you.
You’re welcome.
I am sorry. About all of it. We gave it a good try didn’t we?

I lived with my parents until I was 23. Then I moved in with Teddy. And I lived with him until I was 91. I’ve lived, just me, for two years now. It’s lonely sometimes. I miss Teddy. But I tried sushi. And I liked that quite a bit. I’ve enjoyed my time alone. I guess I wanted more.
I think I know her.
Lois?
We’re headed to 21821 San Fernando Road.
We’ve come this far. Let’s finish it.
What about your show?
There is no show without Daddy Warbucks.
...We used to call bread the staff of life. Now nobody wants to eat bread. But there are delicious breads that are made now. It’s a conundrum.
People seem to like toast. With toppings.
It’s interesting. The way we think about bread has changed so.
...You want bread? We have bread. Ben pulls a piece of bread in a ziploc out of his jacket pocket. They tear it in half and share it.
I can’t chew it.
It’s like a rock.
Come on, we’re gonna lose him.
Keep a lookout. I’m gonna try to talk to them. If things get funny, you go for help.
How will I know?
You’ll be with me.
Hello?
Seems like there’s a door. In the back.
Two steps to your left. Straight for five paces.

There’s a stack of loose hummels, or maybe they’re gnomes? Some kind of little animals? On your left. Keep your distance. It’s like the scene in the action movie where the hero avoids detection by lasers. If the lasers were delicate antiques.
Gets a little hairy up ahead. Take your time.
Thelma?! You alright?
I’m okay.
Good. Well done, Thel.
What are you doing?
It’s a mess.
Don’t-- don’t clean.
You have to pick up glass. It’s not right.
I’d like to report a robbery--
Thel? ...Thelma?
Talk to me, Thel! What’s going on?
I’m terribly sorry for the imposition...
I beat him up.
Okay. Where’s the mouse. There’s the mouse. Come on, move.
What is this? A shoe?
Looks like a shoe.
Top right.
I x’d it!
That’s it?
I think that’s it.
He can’t get it back?
He can’t get it back.
Don’t take people’s money. Clean up your store. Be nicer to Michael.
And don’t smoke.
Likewise! You have some wonderful hats back here.
We’re famous.
Today was a good day.
I hope you know I’ll be buying you a new scooter. And a new phone.
Maybe we can go for lunch soon. Do a proper catch up.
I’d like that. We could try the famous Belwood cafeteria. I hear they’ve got terrific melons.
Or we could go out.
Both good options. We’ll make a plan, dear.
